content: The "Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007" emphasizes the importance of preventive medicine in reducing healthcare costs and improving public health. It highlights the need for more public health professionals and increased focus on preventive methods to address chronic conditions. The Act also recognizes the decline in preventive medicine residency programs and the importance of a strong preventive medicine workforce. The "Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007" promotes preventive medicine to reduce healthcare costs and improve public health. It allows the Secretary of Health and Human Services to pay up to $20,000 of medical education loans for eligible preventive medicine physicians who receive board certification between 2008 and 2012. Physicians must apply for this payment by submitting an application with required information. Key terms include "eligible preventive medicine physician," "medical education loan," and "school of medicine." The "Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007" authorizes the Secretary of Health and Human Services to pay medical education loans for eligible preventive medicine physicians at a school of medicine. The term "school of medicine" is defined in the Public Health Service Act. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012. SEC. 4. WELLNESS PROGRAM EMPLOYER CREDIT. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section for a Wellness Program Employer Credit. The Wellness Program Employer Credit allows eligible employers to receive a tax credit of 25% of expenses incurred to develop and implement a qualified wellness program, with a maximum credit of $200 per qualified employee. Eligible employers must keep accurate records of employee participation in preventive services and programs. The qualified wellness program for eligible employers includes health risk assessments, preventive services, counseling sessions, and seminars on smoking, obesity, and stress management. The qualified wellness program for eligible employers must offer annual counseling sessions and seminars on various health topics, with at least 50% of full-time employees participating as qualified employees. The section outlines the requirements for a qualified participant in an eligible employer's wellness program, including participation in annual preventive services and a health risk assessment. This provision does not apply after December 31, 2012. The amendment to Section 38(b) of the Code adds a new paragraph for the wellness program employer credit. Additionally, the table of sections is updated to include the new item related to this credit. The wellness program employer credit under Section 45O and the wellness program participant credit under Section 25E of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. The wellness program employer credit allows a $200 tax credit for qualified employees who are full-time and participate in the employer's wellness program. Qualified participants must engage in at least 2 annual preventive services and undergo a health risk assessment. A qualified wellness program for eligible employers includes conducting health risk assessments, offering preventive services recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, and providing counseling sessions and seminars on various health topics. A qualified wellness program for eligible employers includes offering annual counseling sessions and seminars on various health topics recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, with at least 50% of full-time employees participating. The term 'eligible employer' must develop and implement a qualified wellness program and maintain accurate records of employee participation in preventive services and other programs during the taxable year. This section does not apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2012. The amendment regarding the Wellness program participant credit applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007.
